content: - Britain and local rulers sign a treaty to combat piracy along the Gulf coast. From this, and later agreements, the area becomes known as the Trucial Coast.
Ambitious construction projects include Dubai's Princess Tower (centre)
- Deal between the Trucial States and Britain gives Britain control over foreign affairs and each emirate control over internal affairs.
- Sheikh Saqr Bin-Muhammad al-Qasimi becomes Ruler of Ras al-Khaymah.
- Oil is discovered.
- The seven emirates form a Trucial Council.
- Oil is exported for the first time from Abu Dhabi.
August - Sheikh Zayed Bin-Sultan Al Nuhayyan takes over as Ruler of Abu Dhabi.
- As independence looms, Bahrain and Qatar join the Trucial States. Differences cause the union to crumble in 1971.
November - Iran occupies the islands of Greater and Lesser Tunb and Abu Musa.

December - After independence from Britain, Abu Dhabi, Ajman, Dubai, Fujayrah, Sharjah, and Umm al-Qaywayn come together as the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Sheikh Zayed Bin-Sultan Al Nuhayyan presides over the federation.
- UAE joins the Arab League.
- Ras al-Khaymah joins the federation.
January - Sheikh Sultan Bin-Muhammad al-Qasimi becomes Ruler of Sharjah.
February - Federal National Council (FNC) is created; it is a 40 member consultative body appointed by the seven rulers.
September - Sheikh Hamad Bin-Muhammad Bin-Hamad al-Sharqi becomes Ruler of Fujayrah.
February - Sheikh Rashid Bin-Ahmad al-Mualla becomes Ruler of Umm al-Qaywayn.
May - UAE is a founding member of the Gulf Cooperation Council; its first summit is held in Abu Dhabi.
September - Sheikh Humayd Bin-Rashid al-Nuaymi becomes Ruler of Ajman.
October - Sheikh Zayed Bin-Sultan Al Nuhayyan is re-elected as UAE president - his fourth term.
June - Attempted coup in Sharjah. Sheikh Sultan Bin-Muhammad al-Qasimi abdicates in favour of his brother after admitting financial mismanagement but is reinstated by the Supreme Council of Rulers.
Foreign workers and expatriates make up more than three quarters of the UAE population
October - Sheikh Rashid Bin-Said Al Maktum dies and is succeeded by his son Sheikh Maktum Bin-Rashid Al Maktum as ruler of Dubai and UAE vice-president.
- UAE forces join the allies against Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait.
July - Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI) collapses. Abu Dhabi's ruling family owns a 77.4% share.
Iran angers the UAE by saying visitors to Abu Musa and Greater and Lesser Tunb must have Iranian visas.
December - Abu Dhabi sues BCCI's executives for damages.
June - 11 of the 12 former BCCI executives accused of fraud are given jail sentences and ordered to pay compensation.
- Iran fuels the dispute over Abu Musa and Greater and Lesser Tunb by building an airport on Abu Musa and a power station on Greater Tunb.
June - Two BCCI executives are cleared of fraud charges on appeal.
- UAE restores diplomatic relations with Iraq; they were severed at the outbreak of the 1991 Gulf War.
November - Gulf Cooperation Council backs the UAE in its dispute with Iran over Greater and Lesser Tunb and Abu Musa .
June - President Sheikh Zayed pardons 6,000 prisoners.
November - Government orders banks to freeze the assets of 62 organisations and individuals suspected by the US of funding terrorism.
November - UAE President Sheikh Zayed Bin-Sultan Al Nahyan dies and is succeeded by his son, Sheikh Khalifa.
December - Sheikh Khalifa announces plans for the UAE's first elections. Half of the members of the consultative Federal National Council will be elected by a limited number of citizens.
Abu Dhabi's Sheikh Zayed Mosque, the UAE's largest place of worship
January - Sheikh Maktoum bin Rashid al-Maktoum, UAE PM and vice-president and ruler of Dubai, dies during a visit to Australia. He is succeeded by his brother, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum.

March - Political storm in the US forces state-owned Dubai Ports World to relinquish control of terminals at six major American ports. Critics of the ports deal feared an increased risk of terrorist attack, saying the UAE was home to two of the 9/11 hijackers.

March-June - Economic changes announced. They include bringing the days of the official weekend into line with Western nations, introducing laws to reduce the dependence on foreign workers and allowing labourers to form trade unions.
16 December - First-ever national elections. A small number of hand-picked voters choose half of the members of the Federal National Council - an advisory body.
April - UAE unveils a national development strategy aimed at making it a world leader.
September - Dubai and Qatar become the two biggest shareholders of the London Stock Exchange, the world's third largest stock exchange.
January - France and the UAE sign a deal allowing France to set up a permanent military base in the UAE's largest emirate, Abu Dhabi.
July - The UAE cancels the entire debt owed to it by Iraq - a sum of almost $7bn.
February - Dubai sold $10bn in bonds to the UAE in order to ease liquidity problems.
March - Sulim Yamadayev, a rival of Chechen President Ramzan Kadyrov, dies after an apparent assassination in Dubai.
May - The UAE withdraws from plans for Gulf monetary union, dealing a blow to further economic integration in the region.

November/December - Government-owned investment arm Dubai World requests a moratorium on debt repayments, prompting fears it might default on billions of dollars of debt held abroad. Abu Dhabi gives Dubai a $10bn handout - $4.1bn to bail out Dubai World.
January - Burj Khalifa tower opens in Dubai as the world's tallest building and man-made structure.
Palestinian militant leader Mahmoud al-Mabhouh is killed in a Dubai hotel, in a hit widely blamed on Israel.
March - UAE joins international military operation in Libya.
April - Five activists who signed an online petition calling for reforms are imprisoned. They are pardoned and released in November.
April - The UAE recalls its ambassador to Iran after the Iranian president visits a Gulf island, Abu Musa, claimed by both countries.
A member of the ruling family in Ras al-Khaimah is put under house arrest after calling for political openness.
July - The UAE begins operating a key overland oil pipeline which bypasses the Strait of Hormuz. Iran has repeatedly threatened to close the strait at the mouth of the Gulf, a vital oil-trade route.

November - Mindful of protests in nearby Bahrain, the UAE outlaws online mockery of its own government or attempts to organise public protests through social media. Since March it has detained more that 60 activists without charge - some of them supporters of the Islah Islamic group, which is aligned with the Muslim Brotherhood elsewhere in Arab countries.
July - Sixty eight alleged members of Al-Islah are jailed on charges of planning to overthrow the government.
November - Trial in UAE of Egyptians and Emiratis accused of starting a branch of the Muslim Brotherhood, which is outlawed in the Gulf state.
January - Sheikh Kalifa, president of the UAE Federal Council and Abu Dhabi's ruler,  undergoes surgery after suffering a stroke.
March - Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain withdraw their ambassadors to Qatar in protest at what they say is its interference in their internal affairs.
July - The UAE announces plans to send an unmanned spacecraft to Mars in what would be the first space probe by an Arab or Islamic country.
August - UAE intervenes in Libya, targetting Islamist militants with air strikes, US officials report.
September - The UAE and four other Arab states take part in US-led air strikes on Islamic State militants in Syria.
November - Amnesty International accuses UAE of carrying out an unprecedented clampdown on dissent since 2011.
UAE publishes its list ''terrorist organisations'', including dozens of Islamist groups and charities.
March - The UAE, Saudi Arabia and Bahrain temporarily withdraw their ambassadors from Qatar after alleging that it has been meddling in their internal affairs.
March - The UAE and four other GCC states take part in Saudi-led air strikes on Houthi rebels in Yemen.
August - The UAE establishes diplomatic relations with Israel.
